With this microphone holder you can transform a simple lav mic into a custom handle complete with your own custom flag if you so choose. I included an IGES file if you want to modify the file and/or add your own text. You can learn more about it here. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G05DJFQmKVw

If you make one please click the I made one with a picture I would love to see it!

Extra Items required:
018 O-Ring 3/4" ID, 7/8" OD, 1/16" Width (8)
Camera compatible lav mic. Handle is designed to allow for 3.5MM jack (1)
Removable adhesive such as hot-glue if you want to remove the microphone. Use epoxy or super glue if you want it to stay attached forever.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

whatever you want

Infill:

10-20%

Items needed are:
018 O-Ring 3/4" ID, 7/8" OD, 1/16" Width (8)
2 mic-clips
1 flag/body or flag and body (together) depending on your print preference.

The assembly is pretty straight forwards. Glue the handle and body together if required. Take the microphone and run the cable through the handle so that the cord sticks out the bottom and the microphone sticks out the top. Secure the microphone to the clip with adhesive of your choice. I do recommend before you attach the bottom clip that you leave a little wire inside so you can pull the clips off should the microphone become damaged. The O-rings roll on into the groves and do not require glue although a dot of CA glue stops them rolling off.

Text can be added various ways, either by paint, stencil, sticker or being put onto the STL in a program like Meshmixer. Choice is yours :)! Once completed go out and enjoy your super cool/custom microphone and feel like a real life news reporter!

This guy will put your beeper in that unused spot under the fpv cam. It also acts as protection to your exposed electronics from head on collisions with say... ninja branches for example. One more also. I also find it helps getting the fpv cam mount lined up when putting the top plate back on.
print in TPU

title: 32mm CCTV Board Case for Video Astronomy

description.text: This is a case to house a 32mm CCTV board that uses an in-cable remote control. The case is 48mm wide which means it will fit into a 2" focuser. the bottom of the case features a 1 1/8" wide circular hole that you can use to mount an old filter cell if you want to be able to attach filters, focal reducer, or extension tube to mount into a 1 1/4 telescope focuser.

author: jonphilpott

The dimensions are a quick guess, you may need to scale it when printing for exact size. The base is 1cm.
An idea to take nophead's stepper-driven worm gear extruder and extend it to drive pinch wheels on both sides of the filament.
I doubt Lego will be strong enough! Feel free to adapt to your materials of choice.

comments.text:
Hi Giles
Yes, I'm aware the Lego is hardly appropriate :-P
I am thinking of using M8 studding for the worm gears, and hobbing some brass discs with my M8 tap held in my lathe to drive the pinch wheels, also hobbed with an M3 tap in the same way to grab the filament. I reckon that by using M8 stud I can just run through 608Z bearings in the chassis to take pretty much all the perpedicular load off the axles.
It'll be a while before I get this done though - I'm still building my McWire clone chassis!
comments.author: michthom

comments.text: Very cool,  I did something like that a while ago, but instead of gearing I used two drive motors, works ever since.
comments.author: Bophoto

comments.text: So...by using two worm drives, the distances between the pinch wheels can be made closer together without effecting the drive mechanisim? Its neat, would love to see the design realised in something other than lego though.   ;)

making a toy plane , this is a test wheel
Puzzle

DO NOT PRINT YET, DIMENSIONS NOT CURRENT

I originally saw the e3d silicone mold, and then found this printable mold, and it inspired me to try it as well. My heater block has different dimensions, so I made this one.

I printed the pieces in pla and filled it in with high temp silicon gasket maker. I will update wth finalized dimesions and more pictures. I purchased the red gasket maker instead of copper, which is a little springier and can still handle the temperatures.

It took about 3 days for the gasket maker to set completely, it isn't meant to be applied so thick. You can see in the first picture my second version i designed. It was too thick some parts so it came out really ugly. I trimmed it up and it fits really well. I accidentally cut the top too far down so it comes up short, but it still works great.

I have the diiicooler and microswiss hotend. With that combination i would sometimes have to set my printer 5-15 degrees warmer than needed because it wouldn't stay hot enough. Now there is virtually no temperature fluctuation, +/-1 degree most of the time.

I am showing in the second picture that even when heated up to operating temps it is safe to touch the gasket. It does get hot, but it isn't going to burn you. Safe!
Overall I am very happy with this so far, I will upload new files and pictures soon.

description.text:
Deltoidal Icositetrahedron Puzzle Lamp Shade - Clover
Print 24 pieces and put them together.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Deltoidalicositetrahedron.gif
After assembly, the diameter of the lamp shade will be
Large version: ~ 18 cm
Medium version: ~15cm
Small version: ~11 cm

Recommended settings:
In stead of commonly used PLA filaments, use Nylon or ABS filaments for higher toughness and resistance to the heat from the lamp.
For Large and Medium versions: Layer height 0.2 mm
For Small version: Layer height 0.15 mm
For all versions: At least 5 perimeter loops to enhance the shear strength

The STL files are modified to have larger tolerances at the vertices for those who feel difficult during assembly.

Compact filament cleaner for mounting on a side of your printer, with holder of PTFE pipe and sensor for detection of jammed / ended filament.
For cleaning of filament I recommend to use part of sponge curlpapers (found in wife/girl/mother's cosmetics or to buy in any drugstore, if you don't want to risk ;) ), it has right diameter and useful axial hole ideal for filament.
For making a sensor you need some other things except printed body:

  • 2x bearing 623 (3x10x4mm)
  • 2x steel axle fi3mm (I used plain part of old drill 3.0mm)
  • bottom roll, it can be plastic/metal/anything but I recommend to do it of teflon. Diameter: 6mm, but important is to do a groove around, without it sliding resistance is too high.
  • upper roll, it is just a pinch roll from old tape recorder, drilled for 3mm axle. Diameter of roll used by me: 9mm
  • hall sensor: I recommend TLE4905, but it can be any other unipolar.
  • 4x neodymium magnet fi3x2mm
  • plastic disk for these magnets. In my case it is made from plexi, but it can be printed. You can also try to use more than four magnets for higher resolution.

I'm using this sensor with Repetier, my configuration for it (with four magnets and extruder steps per mm = 196.30) is as below, of course without semicolons. Sensor should be connected as Xmax end-switch, without any other elements, just connect Vcc to Vcc, GND to GND, Out to Signal input.

;#define EXT0_JAM_PIN ORIG_X_MAX_PIN
;#define EXT0_JAM_PULLUP 1

;#define JAM_STEPS 2944
;#define JAM_SLOWDOWN_STEPS 4400
;#define JAM_SLOWDOWN_TO 70
;#define JAM_ERROR_STEPS 6000
;#define JAM_MIN_STEPS 30
;#define JAM_ACTION 1

comments.text: Shouldn't this would work with bipolar hall effect if you alternated poles on the magnets?
comments.author: EasyEJL

comments.text:
Bipolar hall sensor also will be ok (with magnets alternately, as you wrote), but in this case there will be half of resolution. You know, with unipolar sensor and four magnets, every round gives you four impulses: magnet/no magnet x4.
With bipolar one impulse comes after two magnets (first magnet switch on, second switch off).
comments.author: EasyEJL

comments.text: makes sense. I figured as much, but I could get unipolars cheap and through amazon prime, or pay more and wait longer for bipolars :) if I have to make a wheel that is larger to fit 8 of the 3mm magnets I will, but calculating the pulse rate shouldn't be hard either to make the settings changes
comments.author: Jarek_P

comments.text: It's not very clear exactly how this works. Can you describe how the hall sensor and magnets fit and function in detail please?
comments.author: BETLOG

comments.text: Hall sensor works like switch. Magnetic field present - it is switched on, not present - off. So, rotating disc with magnets, continuously switches on and off this switch and makes impulses, which are counted by printer logics.
comments.author: BETLOG

comments.text:
Interesting!
Does it ever generate false-positive results? Have you experimented with pausing it while the print is paused (for filament change or nut insertion)?
comments.author: Jarek_P

comments.text: False results - do you mean false impulses from e.g. external magnetic fields? Absolutely not! Hall sensor needs quite big field to see it, so there I hadn't such problems. Anyway, in the beginning I had some other problems with my RAMPS, sometimes it "froze" during counting and despite my device still generated impulses, there was "jam" detected, but this issue disappeared after changing of parameters a bit, it looks that it needs to trim these parameters by own to particular example.
comments.author: BETLOG

comments.text: From EM fields, yes. But not from effecting the sensor directly, but from the way they tend to induce current in the wires if they are not shielded or twisted. From what you said it sounds like maybe you have experienced this and managed to work around it by changing parameters.
comments.author: Jarek_P

comments.text: don't think so my problems was caused by external magnetic fields. My sensor is mounted away from the wires with higher current, only it's own powering is near, but here is very small current, no risk.
comments.author: BETLOG

comments.text: Nemas are probably the biggest EM source on a 3d printer.
comments.author: Jarek_P

title: Centering plate for Thorlabs kinematic mirror mount (Reloaded)

description.text:
This is an improvement of a previous Centering plate for Thorlabs kinematic mirror mount (thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:259018).

When you use a Thorlabs KM100 kinematic mount to hold a mirror, the reflecting surface is displaced from the center of the mounting post. As a result is not easy to align the input and output beams using the grid of the optical table. This simple piece allows shifting the mirror surface to the post center facilitating the alignment.

Description

In this version, M4 nuts are added so that the component can be tightly fixed to the kinematic mount and to its post holder. The file nuts_and_bolts.SCAD is required to generate the nuts.

Materials

  • 2 M4 standard nuts
  • 1 printed component

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/79zJrpXOOyk
This is a quick and eco-friendly way of putting 100m coils of PLA or ABS onto a spool for easy loading into your 3D printer, assuming of course that you have access to a Laser Cutter. ;)

Buy a 100m coil of a really neat colour of PLA or ABS Filament from somewhere like Faberdashery. Discover to your horror that it's just a bare coil of plastic in a bag! How am I going to print that featured Thing now? I'll have to print all the bits for a filament reel and wind the plastic onto it first.
Never fear! make your own out of the box it came in!
Cut one copy of the Cylinder and two Discs.
Bend the Cylinder and insert the tabs into the slots in the Disc.
Drop your coil of filament over the Cylinder.
Now fit on the second Disc and run some hot-melt glue around the inside of the tabs to hold it.
If the spindle that supports your reels is not a solid tube (like the Ultimaker) then a 54mm diameter postal tube has the correct 52mm internal diameter to fit. Just cut off a 75mm length and glue in the centre of the spool.
Load it up and it print!

title: Coral Encapsulation ( Voronoi Style How to...)

description.text:
Here is a simple technique for encapsulating an object with Voronoi style Coral effect.
I have attached video giving a simple Walkthrough on how to do this using Blender. (If you "like" Watch to the end and see how i place an unsuspecting object into the print ....Magic)
http://youtu.be/ge-EKxWPy2Q

comments.text: Cool!
comments.author: Austin

comments.text:
Hmmmm Good idea ...A magnetic mount would be a neat addition ( as fridge magnet for example).
I dont think my ultimaker has an effective Zstop ... i can pause the print however it stays in one place and does a mini meltdown of the surrounding print. A Zstop with a slight Zup 2mm would be most desirable and on resume Zdown 2mm.
This is the fourth encapsulation i have made .. the first ones i slowed the print to snails pace to help , however i felt bashful&confident with the one you see in the video...
The gcode generated by Cura prints in a clockwise/anticlockwise direction meaning that the centre of the print is never passed by the print head ... only at the end when the crown is capped.. so objects can be placed quite early on in the print.
comments.author: Austin

title: Origami Parabolic Shape from a paper square

description.text: I've folded this shape quite a few times, inspired by the work of Eric Demaine (Check out his work, he's brilliant!), among others. Folding this from a square without any other aids than your hands is a time consuming chore. This simple DXF cuts a square from an A3 size piece of paper and dashes the folding lines, making the process considerably less time consuming and a lot easier. BEWARE: The dashes I've used may not work with your CNC laser/software setup. If it doesn't, select all the lines except the edges and go to the "object properties" or similar in your CAD software menu. Choose "slashed" or a similar alternative and play around with different ones until you find one that works for you. To fold the shape, just zigzag the folds, starting with the outer edge. All the edges circumventing the square folds in the same direction. The next edge folds the opposite way. Squash the corners carefully along the diagonal lines. If you look at the pictures, you'll get the um... picture... It gets a bit harder as you get closer to the centre, but if you take it easy and start in the middle of each side, you'll get there in hardly any time at all. I love the way this object naturally takes it shape. It's mathematics, you know. And a dash of physics. If you love this shape as much as I do, you are very probably a nerd. There's nothing wrong with that. Nerds rule the world. Be proud.

comments.text: An alternative to laser cutting this thing is to print the design on a regular printer and use a ruler to score the slashed lines with a sharpish object (a butter knife with a dull edge or something similar will do well), just press down hard enough to make a ridge you can fold along. This takes more time than using a laser cutter, but it works and it'll look nice.

There's something to be said for the excitement of topwater fishing....this my version of a 3D printed topwater minnow lure.

Assembles just like my Crankbait Fishing Lure.

I tested these out and they swim pretty well and have lots of wobble action. When twitched on the retrieve they have a pretty good wounded minnow look to them.

The lure was designed to use BB's for weight to achieve the desired flotation. See images below for examples.

I used #10 Treble Hooks and #2 Split Rings on these.

If you print one and actually catch something on them post a "Make" I would love to see your catch.

If you have any questions or problems with the files or fitment of the parts just let me know and I will try to fix them.

Remember to tip your waiters designers if you like the service.... thanks for looking

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

No

No

.10

50%

Notes:

There are some thin areas of this lure so like all my lures I printed this with a .25 nozzle.

Using just 2 BB's in the front two holes produces a nice level floation postion much like a store bought floating minnow. The green painted bass lure has 5 BB's installed in produces a countdown lure action when not being retrieved and it will sink until the rear hook touches the bottom and then floats at a up angle. The blue one has 4 BB's and will raise very slowly back to the surface when the retrieve is stopped and floats at a 45° angle. I'm sure the sunfish will love pecking at this one.

comments.text: Super glue is just a brand... but any CA (Cyanoacrylate) type glue should work.  I actually use stuff that is sold as a motorcycle grip glue.

I am using pla at 200 degrees and have tried slowing down to 30 mm/sec print speed to let it cool but I am still having the problem.  .1 layers at 50% infill.  I also went to 1mm top and bottom thickness to try to give a bit more support.

author: arnew

title: Bearing spool holder with adjustable brake

description.text:
Spool holder with adjustable brake (to avoid uncontrolled unroll) for 51mm spool.

For making it you will need also:

  • two bearings 6905 (25x42x9mm),
  • any compression spring with dimensions more/less similar to standard extruder spring, but with thinner wire, original is too hard. My spring has a wire 0,5mm , I found it somewhere in my workshop, between a lot of "things that can be useful"
  • slice of felt (thickness 1-2mm), which has to be glued at the end of brake.

After assembling brake has to be set to provide not so big friction, just to avoid free rotation, not higher.

description.text:
How to draw fungus in Rhino

  1. create two surfaces 'from network of curves' (cirkels and open curves)
  2. copy the outer surface
  3. use 'blend surface' to connect the inside and the outside surface and 'create solid'
  4. paste the outside surface and 'extract wireframe', 'trim' and 'tube' the vertical lines
  5. use 'boolinan difference' to remove the tubes and create the gills

description.text:
For the single guy that wants to move a wardrobe but not bother his friends.

Clamp these to your wardrobe and just roll with it.

You'll need

  • 4 Prints of Base
  • 8 Prints of Knob
  • 8 Prints of Pad

You'll also need

  • 8 m3 x 30mm bolts
  • 24 m3 nuts
  • 16 8G by 16mm timber screws (well they've worked for me, might want to try 6G)
  • 4 castor wheels

For the castors I used 50mm x 53mm soft finish castors with a 42x42mm fitted plate. They have a max load of 30kg per castor and 90kg maximum total. I wouldn't suggest going anywhere near that with printed plastic parts.

Printer:

Prusa I3 Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed with rafts just to ensure good bed adhesion, and I used 40% infill for more strength (these are probably the heaviest thing I've ever printed)

Installing Nuts

Tolerances are pretty tight on this print, I had to use a clamp to force the nuts into the captive holes.

Put nuts in every captive hole you can find, there should be two in each Base, one in each Knob and a further one in each Pad.

It pays to thread a smaller m3 threaded screw into the Knob nuts and use that to force them deeper, it gives you a few extra mm of clamping ability.

Install the bolts

Thread the bolt fully through Knob, from the nut side to the flat side, I put a little bit of Loctite on it before screwing it home.

Thread the bolt through the outside of the Base (this should just slip through but might require some turning) and screw into the nut on the inside of the Base.

Apply a little Loctite inside the nut on the Pad (I also used some CA to help hold the outside, not sure how that'll hold) and screw that onto the protruding end of the bolt inside the Base.

Set aside for the curing time of Loctite

Apply castor wheels

So, I made the castor wheel holes in the Base a touch further apart than they needed to be for my castors so I could put the screws in at a slight angle making sure they don't put too much pressure on the inner wall (which is probably a touch thin, but I was aiming to get the most clamping room I could)

Place the castor wheel on the Base and start screwing the first screw in at a slight angle, go 2 or 3 turns (just enough to be sure it's not going to fall out) then move to the diagonally opposite corner and start screwing that one in on an angle.

Repeat for the other 2 screws before tightening them all down.

There is room for a 3/8" x 3/4" piece of hook velcro in the middle if you use velcro on your packs. The extra pieces makes a big difference in retention I find.

Excerpt from wikipedia:
Thunderbird 2 is International Rescue's heavy-duty transporter aircraft which carries rescue equipment to the danger zone in one of 6 pods (including Thunderbird 4 in pod 4). Thunderbird 2 is a large, green VTOL aircraft that is used in most earth-based rescue missions. It is piloted by Virgil Tracy, who is often accompanied by either Scott Tracy, Alan Tracy, Gordon Tracy, Brains or sometimes Tin-Tin. Thunderbird 2 is 250 feet (76 m) long with a wingspan of 180 feet (55 m) and a height of 60 feet (18 m). A long-range craft, it is capable of reaching anywhere in the world without refuelling and has a maximum speed of 6,000 mph (9,700 km/h) (but cruises at 2,000 mph (3,200 km/h)). It therefore arrives at the danger zone later than Thunderbird 1.

author: VanAllesWatOntwerp

title: Quick change wall mount for HTC Vive Lighthouse

description.text:
EDIT: I've added a home base version that has the same hole pattern as the stock mount, that way you don't have to drill new holes

EDIT 2: I've added a "Home Stubby" version that is only ~60mm by 90mm, and should fit on a M3D printer.

This mount uses a tapered sliding dovetails joint (from woodworking) to allow the Vive Light house to be quickly and securely mounted and unmounted without any tools(after initial setup) or complex mechanisms.

The benefits of this mechanism are that its friction based joint is fundamentally wobble free and it is un-affected by poor printer tolerance.

The mount is made out of two parts.

The first is a puck that is mounted to the Lighthouse base. It should be assembled in this order: screw head - puck - lighthouse base - nut, making sure the puck is oriented so the screw head sits in the counterbore

The second part is wall mounted grove plate to accept the puck. It MUST be mounted WIDE SIDE UP. It can be securely/perminatly screwed to a wall, or it can be used with double sided tape or velcro if you are bold.

I have a set of groove plates permanently mounted in my vive space, and a travel set using Velcro command strips. when I set up at a friends house, I leave the mating Velcro strips on the wall, which makes setting up in the future easy.

To use the assembled mount, align the puck to the grove (Wide ends UP) and slide the puck firmly down into the groove. Everything should tighten up and be wobble free. to remove the Light house just lift it out of the groove.

Designed in OnShape

if you have onshape you can copy and remix the part to your needs.

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/7a884c666e193f5b0391cc5a/w/42d669a1fc2b6cafa1a88086/e/4f418c32f50c2beddc24dea0

comments.text: This is neat, but the most important thing I've learned here is they make Velcro Command strips, I need to find some of those. :O

comments.text: What a HORRIBLE idea...

comments.text: This is great! I printed the "stubby" version of the wall mount both flat on the print bed and standing up on the narrow end. I feel a little more confident in the mechanical strength of the ones I printed standing up because the flanges that hold the puck aren't aligned with the print layers. I can imagine layers separating and letting my expensive base stations fall to their doom! I've printed parts that undergo a lot more stress and have seen layers separate... but I think either way will work fine for the normal stress this piece is meant to endure. Thanks!

comments.text: 10-30% would be fine. These mounts interlock in a way that leaves no play between the printed parts, regardless of how accurately or solidly they are printed. Just make sure they are mounted to the lighthouse and the wall securely.

title: Intex pool inlet to garden hose adapter

description.text:
This thing is meant to connect an Intex pool inlet (3th image) to a standard garden hose click connector (4th image). One of the things you can do with it is connect a pool vacuum cleaner (one that needs water to go in it) to the inlet. So you don't have to use tap water while vacuming. I haven't printed it yet so it is not tested. I will update as soon as I tried it. I used the garden hose coupler by Lampmaker.
I used threads.scad by Dan Kirshner.
Remember you have to put a rubber ring around the top of the garden hose connector. You can buy it in a DIY centre.

comments.text: Printed this twice...It does work, but the threads aren't a perfect match, good enough but it doesn't just thread on easily.  Getting the support right is very tricky.  Since the little tube inside doesn't reach the bottom it needs support...but with slic3r that also adds support to the o-ring groove at the top and removing that is VERY tricky because of how thin the nozzle is behind the o-ring.

remixed_from.author: GeoDave
remixed_from.title: Folger Tech Sliders and Carriage Remix for Limit Switch Micro Adjustment

title: Folger Tech Sliders and Carriage Remix V2

description.text:
Rev17 Slider for M6 Wheel Screws
As per a request I added a slider to use M6 holes for the wheels instead of the M5 holes.
The STL files & openscad files for those have M6_ as the prefix of the names.

Rev23 Carriage
I had to add a little more access room for Right Rod Locknut.

I am changing the original hotend to the e3d Lite6, so since I have to re calibrate it anyway, thought I would change the carriage & sliders while I was at it. This is a remix of my previous remix. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1676013. More detailed info can be found on that link.

The carriage design I changed the top connection to use a self clamping of the belt. I added 2mm more of space for the belt to clear the bottom clamped belt. The openscad file for the carriage has an option for the bottom hole pattern to have both holes or a Right or Left. I also chamfered the top edge of the carriage to clear the limit switch board.

I printed 3 each of 1xsliderv2_Mod_Rev16.stl & 1xCarriage_Mod_M3_Left_Rev23.stl at 50% infill PETG. If you want to print all 3 at a time, use 3xsliderv2_Mod_Rev16.stl & 3xCarriage_Mod_M3_Left_Rev23.stl

There is not that big of a change to slider other than giving the design a little more Z height. The 2 wheeled side of carriage is on the opposite side of original design so the limit switch board does not hit the top wheel mount. My height with the other design is 288mm. Should be 5 to 8mm higher with this design. Not that much height gain, but every little bit helps sometimes. The only change in hardware I made from my previous design was to shorten the micro adjust bolt from 12mm to 10mm.

The hardware I used was:
Original 3x M5x25mm Countersunk screws for the Wheels
M3x22mm cap screw for Wheel Tensioner instead of the original M3x20mm screws
M3x10mm cap screw for the Micro adjust screw
M3 Jamb Nut for Micro adjust & Wheel Tension screw
Original 2x M3x20mm screws to mount top of carriage
M3x12mm cap screw to mount bottom one side of carriage

I also changed the effector design to convert to openscad & add a print fan & will upload that design after testing that one. I have not installed this new version yet, but seems like it should work. I will add photos after installing this.

Without having to take the top 3 vertices off, this is the order in which I reinstalled these.
Remove and Replace one carriage at a time.

Removal Procedure

  1. Remove the 2 rods 1st. The captive nut design for this have access holes to the captive locknuts for the rods to insert an allen wrench into to hold the locknut still in case it wants to rotate.
  2. Remove the wheel from the side with only one wheel.
  3. With the Slider/carriage removed, remove all the other hardware from the old parts.

Install Procedure

  1. After removing a carriage, bolt the Top wheel on 1st since part of that screw head is covered by carriage.
  2. Add 10mm micro adjust limit screw & jam nut (8mm or 12mm will probably also work).
  3. Add 22mm wheel adjustment screw & jam nut.
  4. Bolt Top of carriage down to slider with 2x M3x20mm screws & locknuts at the top.
  5. Bolt Bottom of carriage down with a M3x12mm screw & locknut.
  6. Bolt the bottom wheel on.
  7. Add the 2 captive locknuts for the rods. The belt clamp side is sometimes tricky.
  8. I find it easier to clamp the top of the belt while the carriage is flat.
    (The way I install the self clamped belt is press it single width thru the groove 1st with a couple of inches extended beyond where it self clamps, overlap about 12mm(1/2") of the belt & pull it back until it is flush with where the vertical belt way slides thru. It might take a couple of tries the 1st time to find the right amount of belt to overlap)
  9. Put the Slider/carriage on side of vertical 2020 & add the other wheel.
  10. Adjust the 22mm wheel screw for the proper tension before installing rods.
  11. Install the 2 rods. There is an access hole at the top for each captive locknut to insert an allen wrench to push against the side of the locknut if turns on you while installing a rod. I did not need it though.
  12. I would wait until all 3 slider/carriages are installed before clamping the bottom of the 3 belts.

The 2nd thru the 6th photo show the order in which I installed these on my machine.

comments.text: Nice design.  How did the PETG work for these parts?  My original sliders broke (I over tightened them) so I printed replacements in PETG, but they seem too flexible.
comments.author: jodyhi

comments.text: PETG worked great for me. I think a little flex makes it less likely to break than using the more rigid pla. You might want to try the PLA+ from eSun if you want less flex. I am starting to print more with that & really like it. The top belt clamp I was not entirely happy with & probably will modify that soon. I am also making the captive nuts for the rods insertable from the top of the carriage instead of from the ends. That will give a narrower belt path where the nuts are & make it easier to tighten if the nut is not a real tight fit in the plastic.
comments.author: jodyhi

comments.text: Thanks for your comment. The project works fine for my needs, but if you want you can improve it as you think. I gradually developed the design for the project according to the materials available to me. If I had time and I would certainly not suitable materials created with the 3D printer, but with a carpentry job. I had available only the screwdriver, the box of coffee and my mind and what I came out, I think, it is very satisfying. The jar was loaded with 500 grams of small self-tapping screws and produces a perfect sanding in about 2 hours of work. The friction problem was solved with a layer of grease to gears and has stabilized after about 4 hours of operation due to friction that produced a polishing effect of the contact parts. The engine is very powerful and if used with a power supply from at least 2 Amps has no problem to move the gear and all the weight of the coffee box. Have you seen my video? The connection between screwdriver and metal bar is made using a tip that fits perfectly hexagonal insert present on the bar.

title: Rack for Raspberry Pi 0, 1B, B+, 2 and 3 on a modular system 19" 2U

description.text:
Hi!

This is a simple rack cover for the modular system for 19" 2u rack!

You have two version, one with 3 holes for led (connected on the GPIO --> Power, HDD Usage and FAIL ( or other )
And one without hole.

EDIT : you can buy the frame part here : https://www.musicstore.de/fr_BE/EUR/DAP-Audio-2-HE-Rackblende-f-Modulsystem-10-Segmente/art-PAH0017160-000

Enjoys !

Please comment if you have some ideas for other cover ;)
(One covers with power distribution and power meter arduino it is in progress )

UPDATE :

  • Add Raspberry ZERO double support ( By Riddleywalker )
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2522240
  • Add Raspberry 1B (By pfml)
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2577853
  • Amazing remix from Tkramm
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2759317

description.text:
Are you missing Mr Todd?

Now he can be with you everywhere you go!

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print with the shed base on the build plate the the "bottom" off the roof on the plate too
Designed in Autodesk inventor

This is the thingy I came up with to mount a bltouch on my Ft-5. I'ts a 3mm backplate and no spacers were needed on the bltouch with a e3dV6.

I printed it at .2 with 100% infill to make it solid could prolly get away with less but why bother...

I did this in sketchup and loaded the file if anyone want to tweak it
A really good stand for your phone!!
